awd_titl_txt: 3D Magnetic and Thermal Structure of Active Regions of the Sun
awd_abstract_narration:
The Sun is the best astrophysical laboratory for obtaining clues to magnetic field structure and activity because the magnetic field can be studied across time frames and physical sizes needed to begin understanding both the complex structure and dynamics of the magnetic field. This project aims to quantify magnetism in the solar corona using focused efforts to study the solar magnetic field. The investigators will create realistic 3-Dimensional (3D) modeling tools to study the basic science problem of measuring the coronal magnetic field structure in solar active regions (AR) and reconstructing AR heating structure. This new modeling will augment the investigators' existing capabilities for AR modeling, and use all of the advanced modeling tools and computer codes they have already developed. The project will make new scientific products such as maps of the coronal magnetic field, and 3D models of individual ARs built using input from observations. This project supports the mission of the NSF by promoting our understanding of magnetic field structure and activity at the Sun.  The research group has established a summer internship research program for high school students in the Union County Vocational Magnet School having concentration on Science, where the tools developed under this project will be heavily used.


This project leverages an extensive, quantitative use of radio data available from a variety of modern radio interferometry arrays and combines these diagnostics with more traditional EUV and optical data as well as coronal modeling approaches based on these data (in particular, nonlinear force-free field modeling). The investigators will employ new science capabilities of the radio imaging spectroscopy data from solar active regions, augmented by advanced theory and 3D modeling of gyroresonance (GR) and free-free emission. The GR process gives radio emission its ability to provide direct measurements in the corona of magnetic field strength and direction, and so provides the key to understanding the basic mechanisms underlying all of solar activity.  Interpretation of the observations relies on construction of comprehensive models for the atmosphere, including both plasma and magnetic field models, which are then matched to the data through forward fitting. These theory and modeling efforts are needed in order to exploit the powerful new radio data coming online now from a number of radio instruments including the VLA, Expanded OVSA (EOVSA), and Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the project was to understand and quantify the 3D magnetic field and thermal plasma in solar active regions based on multi-wavelength observations and realistic data-constrained 3D modeling. The magnetic field that competes with other forms of energy, such as gravitational, nuclear, or kinetic, is dynamically important in many areas in modern astrophysics. The Sun, however, is arguably the best astrophysical laboratory for obtaining clues to magnetic field structure, its interaction and its evolution, because it can be studied at the temporal and spatial scales needed to begin resolving the magnetic field spatial complexity and at least some of the dynamical phenomena that can occur. This project significantly improved our ability of 3D reconstructing the magnetic and thermal structure of solar active regions (ARs) using modern high-resolution observations and advanced theory and modeling. The uniqueness of the project is an extensive, quantitative use of radio data from very broad spectral range available from a variety of modern radio interferometry arrays and combining these diagnostics with more traditional EUV and optical data as well as coronal modeling approaches based on these data (in particular, nonlinear force-free field modeling). We employed new science capabilities of the radio imaging spectroscopy data from solar active regions, augmented by advanced theory and 3D modeling of gyroresonance (GR) and free-free emission.  The GR process gives radio emission its ability to provide direct measurements in the corona of magnetic field strength and direction, and so provides the key to understanding the basic mechanisms underlying all of solar activity.  Like other remote sensing measurements of the corona, interpretation of the observations relied on construction of comprehensive models for the atmosphere, including both plasma and magnetic field, which are then matched to the data through forward fitting.

 

Intellectual merit. We substantially improved theory of thermal microwave emission from solar (stellar) atmosphere. The new theory accounts for all relevant physical effects and parameter regimes: chemical composition, temperature-dependent ionization, collisions of electrons with both ions and neutrals, exact Gaunt factor, effect of magnetic field, and mode coupling during the radiation transfer. The theory also permits the plasma to be described by the density and emission measure over the temperature within any elementary volume element, rather than by a single pair of n, T values. The theory is implemented in freely available computer codes. We demonstrated that spatial distribution of synthesized GR emission from ARs critically depends on the model assumptions of the coronal heating mechanism. For an instance of AR 11520, for a subset of parametric heating models, we obtained an almost perfect match between the synthesized and observed distributions of the radio brightness, which validates the developed 3D model of this AR. This finding opens a new avenue of probing the coronal heating law. This methodology does not depend on the poorly know elemental abundances in the corona and, thus, supersedes a more usual diagnostics based on the EUV data. We employed non-linear force-free field extrapolation of coronal magnetic fields above AR 11944 to detect signatures of several magnetic flux ropes present at the eruption site several hours before the eruption itself. Major upgrades of our modeling tool, GX Simulator, have been released via SolarSoftWare (SSW) repository. These upgrades include (i) new EBTEL-generated DEM/DDM lookup tables, (ii) ability to compute thermal radio emission from DEM/DDM distributions, (iii) new model to data comparison tools, and (iv) coronal heating modeling pipeline.

Broader impacts. All project personnel has been trained in using the interactive GX Simulator and coronal heating modeling pipeline tools. Tutorial for other potential users of these products were performed in several scientific meetings. Six high school students have been trained in using our modeling tool, GX Simulator. Nine research papers were published. Many seminar and conference presentations have been performed or scheduled. Numerous press-releases and media coverages highlighted our activities. Several interviews were published by popular science resources. The measurements of evolving coronal magnetic field and thermal plasma evolution have been reported. Our modeling tools are being used for in-class demonstrations. Our new 3D modeling, visualization, and analysis tools have a great level of generality, while are very simple in the use, having high level of interaction and great flexibility in setting up the geometry and plasma properties. These are highly helpful in the presentation and teaching along with the research in the solar physics. They represent the most general, flexible, and convenient modeling tools developed so far and freely available for the community. The tools are already widely used for immediate teaching goals and dissertation projects in the Center.
